title: How to Use Picasa to Make Nametags

steps.headline: To prepare, this process works best if your pictures are similarly sized and preferably in landscape orientation.
steps.description: Click on the images if you need a bigger view, as some of them contain small details relevant to this tutorial.

steps.headline: Install Picasa on your computer.
steps.description: For this tutorial I will be using the Windows version, but the Mac one is pretty similar. Picasa is a free photo managing program from Google and can be found at https://www.google.com/picasa/.

steps.headline: Once you're through the installation process, open up Picasa.
steps.description: It will ask you a few questions/options, just choose what you want. Once you're finished and have Picasa ready to go, on the top bar go to "File" then choose "Add Folder To Picasa...".

steps.headline: Choose the folder containing the pictures you want to use for the name-tags.
The photos should be added fairly quickly.
steps.description: Find the new folder you added in the lower left corner of Picasa and click it. Your pictures should be brought into view.

steps.headline: Double click the first one to bring up the "Edit" view.
Now we need to add "Captions", which will be the names for the guests.
steps.description: At the bottom of the picture there should be a bar that says "Make a caption!". If there isn't, click the little grey square in the bottom left of the viewing are to bring it up. Click on the bar and then type in the first person's name.

steps.headline: Once you've entered the first person's name, press enter to save the caption.
steps.description: Then, press the right arrow to continue to the next picture. Continue the process until no un-captioned photos remain.

steps.headline: Click the button to go "Back to Library".
Select the photos you want to print.
steps.description: You can do this by right clicking the folder containing the now captioned photos, or by manually using Ctrl or Shift to select individual pictures.

steps.headline: Click the "Print" button at the bottom of the screen.
Choose how many tags you want per page.
Choose either to shrink the picture or to crop the picture.
steps.description: Cropping is probably the best idea.

steps.headline: Open up "Border and Text Options".
steps.description: Choose the "Caption" option for text. The rest is your preference to play around with (font and size, etc.). It looks nice to add a border. You can also choose where the text is placed. Press "OK".

steps.headline: You can now change your printer options, or you can leave them.
steps.description: Press the "Print" button once you're ready. Now just wait for the tags to print out!

text: To prepare, this process works best if your pictures are similarly sized and preferably in landscape orientation. Click on the images if you need a bigger view, as some of them contain small details relevant to this tutorial. Install Picasa on your computer. For this tutorial I will be using the Windows version, but the Mac one is pretty similar. Picasa is a free photo managing program from Google and can be found at https://www.google.com/picasa/. Once you're through the installation process, open up Picasa. It will ask you a few questions/options, just choose what you want. Once you're finished and have Picasa ready to go, on the top bar go to "File" then choose "Add Folder To Picasa...". Choose the folder containing the pictures you want to use for the name-tags. Click the "OK" button. The photos should be added fairly quickly. Find the new folder you added in the lower left corner of Picasa and click it. Your pictures should be brought into view. Double click the first one to bring up the "Edit" view.  Now we need to add "Captions", which will be the names for the guests. At the bottom of the picture there should be a bar that says "Make a caption!". If there isn't, click the little grey square in the bottom left of the viewing are to bring it up. Click on the bar and then type in the first person's name. Once you've entered the first person's name, press enter to save the caption. Then, press the right arrow to continue to the next picture. Continue the process until no un-captioned photos remain. Click the button to go "Back to Library".  Select the photos you want to print. You can do this by right clicking the folder containing the now captioned photos, or by manually using Ctrl or Shift to select individual pictures. Click the "Print" button at the bottom of the screen.  Choose how many tags you want per page.  Choose either to shrink the picture or to crop the picture. Cropping is probably the best idea. Open up "Border and Text Options". Choose the "Caption" option for text. The rest is your preference to play around with (font and size, etc.). It looks nice to add a border. You can also choose where the text is placed. Press "OK". You can now change your printer options, or you can leave them. Press the "Print" button once you're ready. Now just wait for the tags to print out!
